channel.title: VB6 help
channel.description:
I'm currently using VB6 to program. I don't really know much about VBscript and I wasn't able to find anything on the internet about this. Basically, I'm just experimenting with the program now, but I'd like to know something.
In my program, you're required to enter a serial code to unlock it. How can I make the program remember that the client has entered a serial? So as not to ask for it next time they run the program. If anyone knows, I'd be grateful if you'd share it, I can't seem to find it anywhere.
Many thanks,
Syrillia.

item.title: VB6 help
item.dc:creator: @Syrillia Syrillia
item.description:
@Syrillia wrote:

Who said I didn’t know what an INI file is. I’d just rather not have an extra file in the there. It make programs look messy. I might go with what nade said and write to the registry. It would probably be one of the most efficient ways to do it. Thanks guys, barring _cake, who seems to be a downright twat.

Syrillia.

Read full topic

item.title: VB6 help
item.dc:creator: @_cake _cake
item.description:
@_cake wrote:

unnamed, if the kid doesn’t even know what an INI file is, what are the chances he knows what offset to write the bytes to.

Read full topic

item.title: VB6 help
item.dc:creator: @nade nade
item.description:
@nade wrote:

Dim valid As String
'; AppName/Registration valid=true
SaveSetting "AppName", "registration", "valid", "true"
valid = GetSetting("AppName", "registration", "valid")

MsgBox valid

Rep me, choob.
[center] We don’t ask for rep.[/center]

Read full topic

item.title: VB6 help
item.dc:creator: @Exception Exception
item.description:
@Exception wrote:

My advice to you, would be to learn a real language, then try again.

Read full topic

item.title: VB6 help
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

vbcoderx:

haha… or if you wanted to add security too, take a look at cruels autologin manger, has reading and writing encrpyted ini files… so in theory, no one could open the ini and get the key…

Even still, writing to a file to show that you have entered a key is a TERRIBLE way to do it.

A more secure way to do it, would write to the application it’s self.

Read full topic

item.description:
@Syrillia wrote:

Did you not understand what ‘…and I wasn’t able to find anything on the internet about this…’ meant. I know what google is for, I just can’t find an answer. Can anyone help? If it’s possible, I’d rather not make a new file for it, but if that’s the only way, then I’ll use that.
